mike woodhouse wrote:

>On Sun, 26 Sep 2004 21:23:37 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>I'm certainly interested in this, although I would imagine that the
>>outcome of sporting events is even more unpredictable than financial
>>markets. Having said that I see no reason to use the confidence output
>>    
>>
>
>No reason to use or no reason *not* to use? 
>
Sorry yeh, no reason not to use it.

>I was rather keen on the
>confidence output - I thought for a while that it was going to be my
>major contribution - until I read the messages discussing the idea on
>this list...
>  
>
At least this means we're all on the same wavelength. I think the 
concept has been mentioned on the list in relation to other problem 
domains and  I recon it's an important idea in general although I've yet 
to use it myself in any experiments.

>>OK well fire away if you have any questions on the C#.
>>    
>>
>
>I'm already working my way through SharpNEAT (lovely job, by the way).
>  
>
Thanks!

>I think the sensible approach is to build the model around your code
>to start with and consider my wackier ideas later once that's all
>running.
>
Hopefully you have found the interface between SharpNEAT 'core' and the 
experiment/evaluation code. I tried to make this minimalistic and simple 
to use, the incremental evolution stuff is perhaps not intuitive to a 
newcomer and to be honest I've only used it in the prey capture domain 
so far, I think it's useful enough an idea to keep around though.

> I've followed the optimisation threads with great interest
>(and learned a lot) - have you come across ArithEMITic
>(http://blogs.geekdojo.net/richard/archive/2004/01/24/742.aspx)? It's
>an approach that uses Reflection.Emit to compile the
>performance-optimised code for a network on the fly.
>
Sounds similar to John Arrowood's approach for his IEX work. John's code 
emits C/C++ that can then be compiled with gcc. Thanks for the link, 
I'll read this later.


> I don't claim to
>understand it, and I don't suppose it would enhance something like
>XOR, but larger models might benefit. Just in case you were suffering
>from an excess of spare time...
>  
>
I tend to think that the optimised neural net code that was cooked up 
here on the list isn't going to be bettered to much, if at all. But I'm 
always interested in investigating possibilities. My concern with this 
sort of approach is that as the networks grow in size, the size of the 
code will also grow and will therefore take longer to compile. So then 
you have to balance that compile time against expected gains at run time 
- so it depends on how many network activations you expect to do per 
evaluation as to whether the approach is beneficial or not. It's 
possible juggle some of the interfaces around a bit in SharpNEAT so that 
the genome decoder routines are passed the expected number of 
activations, they can then decide on the best decode routine and type of 
network to decode to.  In fact I already use a similar and very simple 
heuristic in the optimised routine I provided in the last release.


Colin.
